bibl.title: Chung Him and Seid Yam v. Henry M. White. Bond for the Release of the Defendant Jung Him
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the Supreme Court of the State of Washington
Filed in the United States District Court
Bond for the Release of the Defendant Jung Him.

p.del: The United States of America, Plaintiff,

div1.p: In the matter of the application of Jung Him et and, for a writ of habeas corpus

BE IT REMEMBERED, that on this 7th day of March, 1922, before me Gordon Mifflin, a notary public in and for the State of Washington, duly commissioned and sworn, residing at Seattle, Washington, principal, and acknowledged himself to owe the United States of America, the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), in Liberty Bonds as follows:
for the sum of $1000.00, and being of the Third Liberty Loan, 4 1/2% Gold Bond of 1928, herewith deposited with the said Court if default be made in the conditions following, to-wit:

The condition of this recognizance is such that whereas on the 6th day of December, 1920, the said Jung Him was by the judgment and decree of this court ordered released and discharged from the custody of the United States Commissioner of Immigration, Luther Weedin; and whereas, the said Luther Weedin, (but by his predecessor in office, Henry M. White), has appealed from said judgment and decree to the Circuit Court of Appeals, and by and order of this court, dated December 6, 1920, it was provided and directed that said Jung Him be released from custody upon the furnishing of a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $1,000.00, to be approved by the United States Districy Attorney:
NOW, THEREFORE, if the said Jung Him shall submit himself to the custody of the said Luther Weedin, as Commissioner of Immigration,

whenever he shall be directed so to do by the Circuit Court of Appeals, and shall abide by and perform any order, judgment or decree that may be made by said Circuit Court of Appeals or said District Court from time to time this and any subsequent term then this recognizance to be void; otherwise to remain in full force and effect.
SUbscribed and sworn to before me this 7th day of March, 1922.
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
